If you look at the scrip (Bottom of photo) seems to be flipped...

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/carlos_ariel_salamantes] Thank you Carlos Ariel Salamantes. We are happy to share it!

Please watch this space for more uploads, you're feedback is always welcome.

comment.author: 36270268@N05
comment._content: This is a great shot - always good to see images from the ANMM collection.

comment.author: 41311545@N05
comment._content:
It would be good to identify this flag, which seems to have three bars and an elephant in the middle. A social  oprganisation's flag I'm guessing. Our group will post here if we find out.
We learn elsewhere that crane rides like this were conducted during Navy Week at Garden Island up to the 1950s, sometimes using the famous 250 ton hammerhead crane [the demolition of which is now being discussed]  but we don't think the crane rides could happen today. There's a lady holding a baby up high above the safety rail in one of the companion photos!

comment.author: 41311545@N05
comment._content: THE FLAG. This information comes from Kim Dunstan of Melbourne, RAN 1958-1967, who does a lot of investigation of our photos, and sometimes extensively so. Kim tells us the flag seen here above the slide chute is the naval ensign of Siam, now Thailand, and probably from the WWI era. We agree. Look closely at your enlarged image and you can see the similarity here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Flying_Naval_Ensign_of_Thailan... Kim also notes that there is an officer in a foreign naval uniform - black epaulettes, collar and dark tie, where an RAN officer's tunic is buttoned to the throat and collar - standing below the crane talking to a lady. The point is, a man in the same uniform can be seen standing fourth from the left in your image of a naval launch, several photos along at Object 00010453. Effectively this ties these two images to the same occasion, and dates the naval launch image for you as Dec. 12, 1931, same as here. We think the men in the launch are those who did entertainment for the children, with a diver looking for 'lost children,' as described in the linked newspaper articles under the companion 'crane basket' image. Well, that's it.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/41311545@N05] Wow, brilliant work on the flag, a huge thank you to Kim Dunstan of Melbourne! I see what you mean by the other image of the naval launch but it is so difficult to be certain. The only issue is that the woman in white, seen hoisted in the crate in this pic, is the same as the one in this image, and the bridge construction is a real anachronism to the proposed date of Dec 1931. See State Records pic of the bridge in Dec 1931. BUT! In the same photo, thought I'm not entirely certain, is another girl - Rosemary Budge. Interestingly, she attended the 1931 party, but was not reported to have attended the 1930 party. Puzzling...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
